Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Story: I sat on the couch, glancing at my husband across the room. He looked tired, his brow furrowed as he scrolled through his phone. I remembered our promise to always talk things through, to share our worries instead of bottling them up. I wanted to ask him what was wrong, to be the supportive wife he needed. Just as I opened my mouth, my phone buzzed. It was Mia, my friend who’d just moved into her new apartment. “Can you hop on a quick video call? I’m lost with this bookshelf and about to give up,” her message read. She rarely asked for help, and I knew she was overwhelmed. I felt torn—my husband needed me to listen, to be present, but Mia was counting on me too. My heart raced as I weighed their needs, feeling the pressure of being a good wife and a dependable friend at the same time.
